<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of BASE64Encode:
```c
static ssize_t
BASE64Encode (const void *in, size_t len, char **output)
{
#define FILLCHAR '='
  const char *cvt = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ"
                    "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"
                    "0123456789+/";
  const char *data = in;
  char *opt;
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t i;
  char c;
  ret = 0;

  opt = malloc (2 + (len * 4 / 3) + 8);
  if (NULL == opt)
  {
    return -1;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < len; ++i)
  {
    c = (data[i] >> 2) & 0x3F;
    opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    c = (data[i] << 4) & 0x3F;
    if (++i < len)
    {
      c = (char) (c | ((data[i] >> 4) & 0x0F));
    }
    opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    if (i < len)
    {
      c = (char) (c | ((data[i] << 2) & 0x3F));
      if (++i < len)
      {
        c = (char) (c | ((data[i] >> 6) & 0x03));
      }
      opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    }
    else
    {
      ++i;
      opt[ret++] = FILLCHAR;
    }
    if (i < len)
    {
      c = data[i] & 0x3F;
      opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    }
    else
    {
      opt[ret++] = FILLCHAR;
    }
  }
  *output = opt;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
opt = malloc (2 + (len * 4 / 3) + 8);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls the C library function malloc to allocate memory; malloc does not call BASE64Encode (no direct or indirect recursive call is made). There are no function pointers or callbacks in this fragment that could cause BASE64Encode to be invoked. Therefore Rule 17.2 is not violated.
